title: 2026 Community Garden Grants (Garden Improvement & Garden Forward)
description: Funding is provided in two tiers—Garden Improvement ($1,500) and Garden Forward ($10,000)—to support the infrastructure, sustainability, and large projects of community gardens.
detailed_overview: The Community Garden Grant program supports community gardens in Clayton, Cobb, DeKalb, Fulton, and Gwinnett counties to help maintain and sustain these important spaces. The 2026 application cycle began in October 2025, with grants distributed at the beginning of 2026. Applicants can apply for two categories of support: the Garden Improvement Grant ($1,500 intended to address infrastructure, supply, and material needs) or the Garden Forward Grant ($10,000 aimed at supporting a larger project that helps the garden thrive). While a garden is eligible to apply for both, only one category of support will be awarded. Additionally, Food Well Alliance offers separate, year-round Labor Support Funding for specialized contractor costs (e.g., irrigation, shed installation).
eligibility: Community Garden Grants are designated specifically for community gardens in Clayton, Cobb, DeKalb, Fulton, and Gwinnett counties. K-12 school gardens are not eligible to apply. Applicants must read the grant criteria before applying. A garden may apply for both opportunities but will only be awarded one category of support.
application_requirements: Requires registering in the online grant system
geography: Clayton, Cobb, DeKalb, Fulton, and Gwinnett counties (Georgia)

title: Capacity Building Grant
funder: Advocates for Urban Agriculture (AUA) in partnership with Food:Land:Opportunity (F.L.O.)
description: This grant funds urban farms and community gardens in the Chicago area to boost the local food economy, production, and distribution through a community-led nomination process.
detailed_overview: The Capacity Building Grant is a fund housed by Advocates for Urban Agriculture (AUA) in partnership with Food:Land:Opportunity (F.L.O.), operating as a model for community-led resource distribution. The funds are intended to support urban farms and community gardens to enrich the local food economy, production, and distribution throughout the Chicago area. The program uses a nomination process, allowing community members or the growing spaces themselves to apply for funds, thereby reducing the administrative burden on applicants. Recipients are selected by an Advisory Committee composed of community residents, including past grantees, growers, or supporters of earth stewardship.
eligibility: Funds support urban farms and community gardens throughout the Chicago area. The application process operates via community nomination or self-nomination.
application_requirements: Completed Nomination Form (via Google Form or document format)

title: Community Development Grant - Small
description: This grant supports eligible commercial, mixed-use, and light manufacturing projects in Chicago.
detailed_overview: Small grants, available up to $250,000, are specifically intended to support eligible commercial, mixed-use and light manufacturing projects. The grants provide substantial funding, covering up to 75% of the total eligible project costs, primarily focusing on projects involving new construction.
eligibility: Intended to support eligible commercial, mixed-use and light manufacturing projects. (Specific organizational eligibility not provided in the content snippet.)
application_requirements: Project must be eligible (commercial, mixed-use, or light manufacturing)

title: Illinois Department of Agriculture Community Garden Plot Reservation
amount: Plot Reservation Fee: $20 per plot (plus optional tilling charge)
description: This program offers individuals and families the opportunity to reserve shared garden plots (organic or non-organic) at the Illinois State Fairgrounds for the growing season.
detailed_overview: The Illinois Department of Agriculture (IDOA) provides 200 plots within the Illinois State Fair Grandstand racetrack infield for individuals and families to grow fruits, vegetables, herbs, and flowers. 100 plots are designated for organic gardening and 100 for non-organic use. This initiative is designed to help urban gardeners or those with limited yard space access affordable growing opportunities. The IDOA provides free water and compost to all registered gardeners. Each plot costs $20, with an additional fee for optional tilling service. Returning gardeners must reserve their previous plot by June 1.
eligibility: Individuals and families seeking affordable space to grow food and plants, particularly those with limited yard space (implied).
application_requirements: Completed application form (online, mail, or in person)
Payment of the $20 plot reservation fee
Returning gardeners must reserve their previous plot by the annual reservation deadline (June 1 for the 2025 season)
geography: Illinois (specifically, the Illinois State Fair Grandstand racetrack infield in Springfield, Illinois)
